awd_titl_txt: Symbiotic Stars and Citizen Science in the Age of Time-Domain Astrophysics
awd_abstract_narration:
1.	Most stars occur in systems containing two or more objects.  Some pairs include a very dense star called a ?white dwarf? ? a star with the mass of our Sun crammed into a volume about the size of the Earth ? plus a red giant star hundreds of times larger than the Sun.  In some cases, called ?symbiotic binaries,? the red giant can transfer matter onto the white dwarf.   Such systems provide clues about the way the evolution of one star affects the other.  They also provide clues about the types of stars that can explode as supernovae, completely disrupting the entire star.  This project will use a robotic telescope called ?SkyMapper? in Australia to search the southern skies for large numbers of symbiotic binaries that previous surveys may have missed.  It will also involve large numbers of amateur astronomers around the world who are members of the American Association of Variable Star Observers.  Their observations will help professional astronomers to determine the true numbers of these systems in the Milky Way Galaxy.

2.	Symbiotic stars are binary systems in which a white dwarf accretes matter from a red-giant companion.  Understanding these systems may have far-reaching implications for binary stellar evolution and may help to constrain the fraction of SNIa that originate as symbiotics.   Arguing that an important, and possibly dominant, sub-population of such systems may have been missed in previous surveys, the Principal Investigator will mine the data provided by the SkyMapper Southern Sky Survey based at the Siding Spring Observatory in Australia to determine the true population of symbiotic binaries in the Galaxy.  The Intellectual Merit of the proposed research stems from the potential for discovering large numbers of previously unknown symbiotics, from determining the true population of such systems in the Galaxy, and from the potential impact of these discoveries on our understanding of binary evolution and the origins of Type Ia supernovae.  The project will also help to prepare the astronomical community to deal with the flood of data expected from the Large Synoptic Survey Telescope (LSST) when it comes into operation early in the next decade.  The project also has unique Broader Impacts: It will foster a close collaboration between the large number of amateur astronomers around the world who are members of the American Association of Variable Star Observers (AAVSO) and professional astronomers to support current and future wide-field time-domain surveys, including those involving the LSST.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE TRUSTEES OF COLUMBIA UNIVERSITY IN THE CITY OF NEW YORK

por.por_cntn:
The scientific goal of this project was to use a telescope that regularly scans the southern sky called SkyMapper to search for a particularly important type of interacting binary star in the galaxy.  With rising community interest in the variable sky and stellar astrophysics, questions of how star systems evolve, interact, and erupt are extremely timely.  Our research aimed to throw the door open on poorly understood interactions in the most common type of multiple star systems: binaries in which both stars have masses similar to that of our sun and the distance between the two stars is about an astronomical unit or more.  These interactions affect the way binary stars evolve.  They lead to eruptions, jets, new modes of mass transfer, and in some cases the type of supernovae used to measure the expansion of the universe.  Our specific goal was to develop a technique for discovering interacting binary stars in which a white dwarf accretes material from a red-giant companion star, and the observable signatures of this interaction are powered solely by the release of gravitational potential energy. We call these systems accreting-only symbiotic stars.

We succeeded. A key outcome of this project is a new methodology for the discovery of accreting-only symbiotic stars that are typically missed in traditional searches based on optical spectroscopy alone. Our methodology combines selection of candidate symbiotic stars based on stellar colors and rapid variability. Candidates are then confirmed with follow-up optical spectroscopy, X-ray observations, and/or more in-depth searches for rapid optical or ultraviolet variability. We expect that other groups are likely to start using our search technique, leading to more discoveries of accreting-only symbiotic stars and meaningful constraints on the fraction of white dwarfs that accrete from red giants that are accreting-only symbiotics. Fully uncovering this previously inaccessible population of interacting binaries will have implications for our understanding of binary stellar evolution (including the formation of cosmologically important supernovae).

Using this methodology, we discovered 12 new symbiotic stars, half of which appear to be accreting-only symbiotics.  We also identified 10 new symbiotic-star candidates. In addition to being important in their own right, these discoveries provide definitive proof that our new search method works. Based on these findings, we concluded that at least 20% of symbiotic stars show optical flickering and are therefore probably accreting-only symbiotics. These binaries would not be detectable with traditional, optical-spectroscopy-based search methods. The true fraction of symbiotics that are powered by accretion alone could even be higher than 20%, and it is not ruled out that the majority of symbiotic binaries are actually powered by accretion alone. In addition, we discovered a portion of SkyMapper color-color parameter space in which almost all objects are symbiotic stars. With this knowledge, we predict the discovery of 40 to 100 new symbiotic stars in future SkyMapper data releases. All of the newly identified accreting-only symbiotic stars (and any discovered in upcoming SkyMapper data releases) are ripe for additional investigations into questions related to jet production, the stability properties of large disks, and even second-generation planet formation. The findings and techniques that were developed in this project are thus likely to have a major impact in the principal disciplines of the project. We have proved that a significant population of accreting-only symbiotic stars exists (and placed a lower limit on its size), requiring a shift in thinking about the nature of symbiotic binaries and even how they are defined.  For example, we showed that the classic signature previously used to identify symbiotic binaries, high-ionization state optical emission lines, is actually not present in many white dwarfs that accrete from red giant stars.

Our search method also uncovered an interesting object that is not a symbiotic star but rather the most luminous quasar in the past 9 Gyr.

The broader-impact portion of this proposal helped lay the groundwork for professional-amateur collaboration on future time-domain surveys such as the Rubin Observatory Legacy Survey of Space and Time (LSST). The partner organization for this award, the American Association of Variable Star Observers (AAVSO), created a website to help communicate the needs of the professional astronomical community to amateur observers via the AAVSO Target Tool. Through this project, the AAVSO continued to develop that Tool and increase its visibility within the professional and amateur astronomical communities. Recently, the AAVSO reached the exciting milestone of 1000 registered users for this new Tool. By supporting the AAVSO's work on a tool to help amateur astronomers find astronomical targets to observe that have scientific value, this project had, and will continue to have, an impact beyond academia (if not beyond science and technology) by improving the ability of citizen scientists to participate in cutting-edge researc


Last Modified: 06/28/2022
Modified by: Jennifer L Sokoloski
